headline: Chef John's Flour Tortillas
description: Love tortillas? These homemade flour tortillas are tender and flavorful. Perfect for your next Mexican-inspired fiesta!

video.description: See how to make easy homemade flour tortillas in no time.
video.name: Homemade Flour Tortillas

name: Chef John's Flour Tortillas

recipeInstructions.text: Whisk flour, salt, and baking powder together in a large bowl. Add vegetable shortening and work into flour mixture using a pastry cutter until it resembles coarse crumbs.
Form a well in the middle of flour mixture and mix in hot water. Work flour and water mixture together with a fork and transfer to a cutting board.
Knead until a smooth, soft dough is formed, about 3 minutes. Add more flour if dough is too sticky.
Place more flour on cutting board, cover dough with bowl, and let rest for 15 minutes.
Cut ball of dough into eight equal parts and cover until needed.
Roll out balls of dough either by hand or with a tortilla press.

Heat a large skillet over medium-high heat. Place flattened tortilla in skillet and cook until it begins to bubble, about 1 minute. Flip tortilla over and cook for an additional minute. Flip again and cook for 1 more minute. Repeat with remaining dough.

review.reviewBody: I have a sodium intolerance. I did not use any salt and used Rumford reduced sodium baking powder. The tortillas came out fine, and I had no typical mouth reactions like when I eat store bought tortillias that can have over 200 mg of sodium per tortillia. This is a keeper.

Chef John saying it will be hard to go back to the packaged option again is an understatement. I'm sure there will be a dark time when in a crunch I will have to buy some from the store, however, I think I will just need to keep these on hand. I used lard instead of vegetable shortening and it produced the lightest and most flavorful tortilla I have ever tasted. They were perfect for pork tacos and I can't wait to experiment with other recipes. The only thing I preferred was rolling them out by hand as opposed to the tortilla press. My tortillas in the press did not come out thin enough for my personal preference. Thanks Chef John!
Excellent as written. Dough really easy to work with. Have also used lard in place of the shortening with great results. So simple will never use store bought again.

No I didn’t make any changes.

You will never buy tortilla's again once you get the hang of these.

For mine, I don't usually have shortening in the house, so I just substituted softened butter. Works wonderfully.

Best tip I can give is you want to make sure the pan is HOT. You want to flash sear these. If they sit in the pan too long, the moisture evaporates and they'll be hard.

My first batch, without resting time, were tough and did not puff. With a little resting time, his flour tortilla recipe is delicious, light, and not greasy.
I used a crepe pan because I own one and it was great! I need to learn how to roll the dough out into a circle, but otherwise, it was tasty and easy to do!
I didn’t have shortening so I substituted butter. They were easy and delicious. My family loved them.

I loved these! They were too big for my tortilla press so I ended up having to roll each one. Next time I'll try to make them smaller so I don't have to roll them out. We loved the texture of these and they were perfect for our shrimp tacos!

These turned out great and were fun to make! Followed recipe exactly. We used a rolling pin to roll out and it was easier just rolling them on the counter top than between waxed paper. First we flattened the dough ball with a plate, then rolled them out thinner. My youngest is a natural at making tortillas it turns out!
First time for doing homemade tortillas, so I followed the recipe exactly. I’m quite pleased with the result. Thanks!
First try at tortillas. I’ll get them a little thinner next time.
Delicious! Mine did not bubble up, maybe because I didn't knead them long enough, but they tasted great. I used a little butter in the pan, which added some yummy flavor.

Yum, I am now a huge believer in making homemade tortillas! I've made them twice now. The first time, I followed Chef John's directions exactly. The tortillas tasted good, but ended up being inflexible and a little gummy tasting. when I went to make them again, I read reviews on this recipe and others to find out what I could do to ensure success. Here's what I ended up changing: I used nearly boiling water, I formed the dough into eight equally-sized balls before allowing the dough to rest, and I only cooked the tortillas for one minute on each side. These changes gave me the results I was looking for, soft and tasty tortillas that were flexible enough to hold filling, but also strong enough not to break when filled. I plan to make these over and over again. They truly are.worth the effort and are.much tastier than store-bought tortillas.
Super easy to make and delicious! Make sure you get your tortilla dough as flat (thin) as possible for best results especially if you’re not using a tortilla press.

Delicious! I used this recipe to make quesadillas! Don't have a tortilla press so the rolling of these tortillas into approximations of circles was time consuming and frustrating. If you have the means, recommend picking up a tortilla press!
awesome recipe!! made them last night, and I agree, we won't be buying them anymore. Fresh is best

I give up. This was my second attempt at making homemade tortillas. The last time was ten years ago, so I thought I had more experience in the kitchen this time around and it would be ok. I realized I didn't have any tortillas in the middle of dinner prep and was trying to avoid an unwanted trip to the store. These came out very dry and crispy like if you tried to roll it up like a taco, it would snap in half. The flavor was good though. So instead of making burritos like I planned, I made a "burrito pie", laying them flat and layering ingredients. They actually worked fabulously for this as they didn't get soggy. Dinner was saved and I may use this recipe again if I plan on using tortillas for the purpose of layering in a casserole-style fashion.
I would add a extra 1/4 tsp of baking powder to get bigger bubbles but otherwise it's a great recipe!

With the taco meat, guacamole, some sour cream, and cheddar cheese, our tacos are definitely so much better than what we'd get at a Mexican restaurant in our city. Thanks so much!

 I like this recipe but I use lard instead of vegetable shortening (Believe it or not lard is so much healthier, the research is all over the place, check the facts).
 Oh and I learned the hard way, make them thin, thin, thin! I place the dough between one side of a gallon ziplock storage bag and a piece of aluminum foil. Then use a large soup pot to do the initial press and then a granite roller.This allows for a thinner tortilla than a tortilla press. I place the tortilla in the pan with the foil still stuck to it, when the tortilla is ready to flip, it will release the foil allowing you to peal it away easily.

loved it, like when i used to get from my spanish friends mom

I've made these before and they are delightful. Today, I splurged on a tortilla press and made a batch of gluten free tortillas. I'll keep working on trying to make them thinner without falling apart. As always, thanks Chef John for your wonderful recipes.

This recipe is so easy to make. I did not have a tortilla press, so I used a rolling pin. It worked just as well. My family devours these before they even hit the table. Thanks Chef John for the recipe!

Followed recipe, except I used butter instead of shortening. I boiled the water to make sure it was hot enough. Used a dry (no cooking oil) nonstick pan over medium high heat. Don't have a tortilla press. I rolled dough out by hand using a heavy jar. I placed dough in between two plastic bread bags beforehand so dough wouldn't stick to my jar while rolling. Came out perfect. Must watch closely or they'll burn. Doesn't take long to cook. Tastes amazing. Looked like the finished product in the video . Hubby and kids ate them all and wanted more. Don't expect these to be like store bought. They're not as pliable, but more like a flat bread. But, they taste so much better. I will be making these often.


******Update******Made these again. After taking them out of the pan, I placed them on a plate and covered it with a lid from one of my pots. They remained covered for about 20 minutes, while I did other things. When I removed the lid, I was pleasantly surprised. They were still warm, but VERY bendable and even more soft. I could use them like burritos or wraps. I love them even more now!
